subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Sweep Tuning of AM Radio Band -
author: Misty Dawn
full_text:
--0-1592443390-1175167101=:63481

--0-1889698378-1175167101=:63481
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

I gave it a try last night and this mornin you guys are right it does work =)
   
  Attaching some of what came thru, way too much to post so I may add it to the site later.
   
  Misty

RetroCom <vfp19968@...> wrote:
          Frank, I got this tonight and it sounds like the same voice swept through several station channels. Could they be talking about the Christopher who uses one of your boxes? 

"Our Chris.....Is giving a reception" 

Dave 

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "Frank Sumption" <franks-boxes@...> 
wrote: 
> 
> WOW!! I am amazed that someonme actually tried this! It does work. 
There was 
> a Danish(I think) researcher doing the same thing, but never could 
make 
> contact with them. I have done this myself, and it can work wiht TV 
too, if 
> you can switch channels fast ennough. I think you could use a 
steeper motor 
> controler to randomly turn a stepper moter, to turn the dial. 
Manually 
> spinning the dial has one advantage, the sound is clearer! I have 
yet to see 
> a method of ITC that produces better results that the random tuning 
methods. 
> 
> Frank 
> 
> 
> >From: " RetroCom" <vfp19968@...> 
> >Reply-To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
> >To: <EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com> 
> >Subject: [EVP-ITC] Sweep Tuning of AM Radio Band 
> >Date: Mon, 19 Mar 2007 17:19:47 -0700 
> > 
> > 
> >I have a very sensitive old AM tuner with a flywheel tuning 
system. I tried 
> >several recording sessions manually sweeping the tuner through the 
AM band 
> >late at night. I got pretty good at keeping the dial moving at a 
constant 
> >rate of speed. This is not nearly as good as Frank's 'hands off' 
random 
> >tuning method but it still produced some results. What impressed 
me most is 
> >that some of the voices sound the same, even though I tuned 
through several 
> >channels. This attached capture could be a technical message. 
> >"Plug a million hertz" One Million Hertz = 1mhz = 1000khz, which 
is close 
> >the center frequency for the AM broadcast band. 
> >Dave 
>
